citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Lindy Lou (900217000254630) a female boxer with six (approximately 4 week old ) puppies, was very thin. Her ribs and
vertebrae were easily seen and palpated. There was a distinct abdominal tuck. Four of the puppies appeared lethargic.
One puppy had watery, yellow diarrhea. One puppy, called Jake, was thin with easily seen ribs. The owner stated that he
was getting milk as a supplemental feeding and they were all getting dewormed daily since some day last week, but there
is no medical record of the treatment. There had been no discussion or consultation with a veterinarian to have a proper
diagnosis and treatment plan. Undiagnosed medical problems can result in improper treatment that may result in the
conditioning worsening. Incorrectly treated medical conditions may cause further suffering and pain and even death. The
puppies and dam must be evaluated by a veterinarian for proper diagnosis and treatment. Records must be available to
APHIS officials.

The 6 Boxer puppies (dam Lindy Lou) had no identification and the owner could not say with certainty how old the
puppies were. Identification is required in order to ensure that each animal's identity can be known with certainty and to
facilitate record keeping requirements that includes the ability to track the dogs that are purchased, transported, traded,
sold, or leave by other methods and for accurate health care documentation. The owner must provide identification at all
times for each puppy born on the premises.
To be corrected by 7 May 2024

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The enclosure containing six four week old Boxer puppies (dam is Lindy Lou) had excessive waste and grime on the
floors and caked material along the edges and corners of the enclosure. The blanket on the floor was stained with dried
diarrhea. The amount of dirt and grime was attracting numerous flies that can bite and irritate the dogs. Due to the
number and condition of the puppies, the enclosure needs to be cleaned and sanitized more frequently and maintained to
ensure a healthy environment.
To be corrected by 7 May 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative
Additional Inspectors:
KONSTANZE PLUMLEE, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Lindy Lou (900217000254630) a female boxer with six (approximately 4 week old ) puppies, was very thin. Her ribs and 
vertebrae were easily seen and palpated. There was a distinct abdominal tuck. Four of the puppies appeared lethargic. 
One puppy had watery, yellow diarrhea. One puppy, called Jake, was thin with easily seen ribs. The owner stated that he 
was getting milk as a supplemental feeding and they were all getting dewormed daily since some day last week, but there 
is no medical record of the treatment. There had been no discussion or consultation with a veterinarian to have a proper 
diagnosis and treatment plan. Undiagnosed medical problems can result in improper treatment that may result in the 
conditioning worsening. Incorrectly treated medical conditions may cause further suffering and pain and even death. The 
puppies and dam must be evaluated by a veterinarian for proper diagnosis and treatment. Records must be available to 
APHIS officials. 
2.50(a)(2) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
The 6 Boxer puppies (dam Lindy Lou) had no identification and the owner could not say with certainty how old the 
puppies were. Identification is required in order to ensure that each animal's identity can be known with certainty and to 
facilitate record keeping requirements that includes the ability to track the dogs that are purchased, transported, traded, 
sold, or leave by other methods and for accurate health care documentation. The owner must provide identification at all 
times for each puppy born on the premises. 
 
To be corrected by 7 May 2024 
3.11(a) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The enclosure containing six four week old Boxer puppies (dam is Lindy Lou) had excessive waste and grime on the 
floors and caked material along the edges and corners of the enclosure. The blanket on the floor was stained with dried 
diarrhea. The amount of dirt and grime was attracting numerous flies that can bite and irritate the dogs. Due to the 
number and condition of the puppies, the enclosure needs to be cleaned and sanitized more frequently and maintained to 
ensure a healthy environment.

To be corrected by 7 May 2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
KONSTANZE PLUMLEE, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
